ratingGuide.guidance: Founder/startup visa is clearly documented, fully online, and typically approved within 2â€“4 weeks with low capital requirements and no local sponsor.
Dedicated entrepreneur pathway with predictable criteria, approvals in under 2 months, and light documentation a small indie studio can handle.
Entrepreneur route exists with moderate capital/proof-of-funds and a 2â€“4 month timeline; legal help recommended but not essential.
Viable but slower pathway (4â€“6 months) with quotas or competitive scoring; supporting evidence and professional filings are expected.
Possible via general business visa requiring substantial documentation, in-person steps, and 6â€“9 month timelines; rejection risk is moderate.
Pathway exists but demands high capital, employer-of-record, or incubator sponsorship; timelines often exceed 9 months.
Rules are opaque, processing is slow/unpredictable, and approvals for small foreign founders are uncommon.
Only niche or exceptional approvals; most indie founders are advised to look elsewhere.
Theoretical route on paper but effectively closed due to quotas, local ownership mandates, or repeated rejections.
No viable entrepreneurship/founder visa path for a small foreign game studio.
Simple annual filing with minimal fees; bookkeeping and payroll are turnkey and under 10 hours per year.
Mostly annual/quarterly digital filings, predictable deadlines, and low compliance hours (<20 per year).
Quarterly VAT/payroll plus annual return; standard software and part-time bookkeeper keep effort reasonable.
Regular filings with occasional in-person steps; translations rarely needed but a part-time accountant is expected.
Multiple agency touchpoints and monthly payroll/VAT; professional accountant required to stay compliant.
High paperwork volume, frequent updates, and notable fees; indie founders spend significant time coordinating vendors.
Complex cross-agency rules with changing interpretations; audits or spot checks are common.
Heavy manual processes, translations, and notarizations; filings routinely delayed or bounced.
Opaque rules, unpredictable penalties, and costly professional support needed for nearly every filing.
Compliance is prohibitively complex or hostile for a small foreign-owned studio.
20+ AA (10â€“50 person) studios active locally, offering a deep hiring and collaboration pool.
15â€“19 AA studios with steady output and networking opportunities.
10â€“14 AA studios; healthy but focused community.
7â€“9 AA studios; noticeable presence with periodic launches.
5â€“6 AA studios; some peers for hiring and knowledge sharing.
3â€“4 AA studios; small but visible niche.
2 AA studios; limited peer network.
1 established AA studio; rare local peers.
Only emerging or short-lived AA efforts; little stability.
No identifiable AA studios in the area.
>=4 recurring in-person events per month, >=2 jams or conferences per quarter, and a local online community with 1,000+ verified members.
3 recurring in-person events/month, >=1 jam per quarter, and 700-999 active local online members plus an annual showcase.
2 in-person events/month, >=2 jams per year, and 400-699 online members with consistent sponsor support.
Average of 1 in-person event/month, >=1 jam per year, and 250-399 online members actively organizing.
6-11 in-person events/year, online hub of 150-249 members, and occasional jams with >40 attendees.
4-5 organized events/year, online community of 100-149 members, limited sponsor engagement.
2-3 events/year with 50-99 attendees and a small online group under 100 members.
1 event/year with <50 attendees; online coordination is ad-hoc with <75 members.
No recurring events but an online chat with <25 local members and no jams.
No organized meetups, jams, or online community for game developers.
Visa filing is straightforward and evaluations have a quick turnaround with minimal evidence required.
Clear rules, responsive processing, and most steps can be done online within 2â€“3 months.
Predictable documentation and 3â€“4 month processing; attorney helpful but not mandatory.
Manageable but requires organized evidence and possibly an interview; 4â€“6 month timeline.
Moderate friction, periodic in-person steps, and 6â€“8 month timelines.
Lengthy or quota-driven processing with notable uncertainty; 8â€“12 months common.
Complex criteria, frequent RFEs, and high rejection risk without expert counsel.
Opaque or discretionary process that is difficult for skilled migrants to navigate.
Approvals for similar skilled migrants are rare; timelines exceed a year.
No practical immigration path for the family profile.
<10% of government, healthcare, and banking interactions require the local language; certified interpreters are available 24/7.
10-20% of critical admin tasks require the local language; most tax, visa, and healthcare forms have official English versions.
20-30% of interactions require the local language; English help desks cover the remainder.
30-40% of interactions require the local language; English is accepted for routine services but not for legal filings.
40-50% of interactions require the local language; English is usable mainly with multinational employers.
50-60% of interactions require the local language; English support exists but often requires paid interpreters.
60-70% require the local language; English assistance is limited to select agencies.
70-80% require the local language; English use is tolerated only in tourist or expat districts.
80-90% require the local language; English is rarely available outside large corporations.
>90% require the local language; English is effectively unsupported for official matters.
>=80% of public K-12 seats offer full English or dual-language tracks starting in kindergarten.
70-79% of seats offer bilingual programs beginning by grade 1.
60-69% of seats offer bilingual options beginning by grade 2.
50-59% of seats offer bilingual options beginning by grade 3.
40-49% of seats offer bilingual options beginning by grade 4.
30-39% of seats offer bilingual options beginning by grade 5.
20-29% of seats offer bilingual options beginning by grade 6.
10-19% of seats offer bilingual options and they begin after grade 6.
<10% of seats offer bilingual instruction and only in upper grades.
No public bilingual/English options; private schools are the only pathway.
Skilled visa approval rate >=95% and national polls show >=70% of residents view skilled immigration positively.
Approval rate 90-94% with 60-69% positive polling.
Approval rate 85-89% with 55-59% positive polling.
Approval rate 80-84% with 50-54% positive polling.
Approval rate 75-79% with 45-49% positive polling.
Approval rate 70-74% with 40-44% positive polling.
Approval rate 65-69% with 35-39% positive polling.
Approval rate 60-64% with 30-34% positive polling.
Approval rate 55-59% with <30% positive polling and rising opposition.
Approval rate <55% plus persistent negative polling and policy backlash.
Median lease secured in <=2 weeks with a single month deposit and digital paperwork only.
Lease in 2-3 weeks; <=1.5 months deposit; translator rarely required.
Lease in 3-4 weeks; <=2 months deposit; notarized documents minimal.
Lease in 4-6 weeks; <=2.5 months deposit; guarantor commonly requested.
Lease in 6-8 weeks; 3 months deposit; multiple in-person visits needed.
Lease in 8-10 weeks; 3 months deposit plus income certification.
Lease in 10-12 weeks; >3 months deposit and guarantor mandatory.
Lease in 12-16 weeks; >4 months deposit or multi-year commitment.
Lease in 16-20 weeks; limited inventory requires waiting lists.
>20 weeks average wait or legal barriers prevent most foreign tenants.
Placement guaranteed within 1 month for infants and preschoolers.
Placement typically in 1-2 months with transparent queue tracking.
Placement in 2-3 months; waitlists move weekly.
Placement in 3-4 months; parents must confirm monthly.
Placement in 4-6 months with periodic documentation refresh.
Placement in 6-9 months; cancellations common.
Placement in 9-12 months; limited infant seats.
Placement in 12-15 months; many families rely on private stopgaps.
Placement in 15-18 months; public seats extremely scarce.
>18 months average wait and no guarantee of placement.

Fragmented offices, limited English support, and repeated document requests consume multiple full days per quarter.
Highly manual processes with unpredictable delays; compliance requires persistent follow-up and often local fixer help.
